description: This PR significantly simplifies our setuptools usage. We no longer rely on `numpy.distutils`. We can *almost* seamlessly install `yt` using `pip install`
title: Refactor setuptools usage

content.raw: This is, without a doubt, my favorite pull request ever.
content.html: This is, without a doubt, my favorite pull request ever.

content.raw: I bet we could make this into a table or something that gets read in from `.json` or gets filled out from a dict; there's so much duplication here that it should cut down a lot on complexity.
content.html: I bet we could make this into a table or something that gets read in from .json or gets filled out from a dict; there's so much duplication here that it should cut down a lot on complexity.

content.raw: Not in this PR, but we should change this description someday.
content.html: Not in this PR, but we should change this description someday.

content.raw: yeah, I was just copy and pasting. I think well written `glob` can match 90% of those
content.html: yeah, I was just copy and pasting. I think well written glob can match 90% of those

content.raw:
Scipy uses this script, which might be helpful:

https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/tools/cythonize.py
content.html:
Scipy uses this script, which might be helpful:

https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/tools/cythonize.py

content.raw: Now that we're no longer using `numpy.distutils`, can we start using `install_requires` so `pip install yt` also automagically installs our dependencies from pip?
content.html: Now that we're no longer using numpy.distutils, can we start using install_requires so pip install yt also automagically installs our dependencies from pip?

content.raw: Haven't tried it yet, but there's is a high chance it'll work out of the box
content.html: Haven't tried it yet, but there's is a high chance it'll work out of the box

I forgot we had this.  It looks to me like only `FindBindingEnergy` from it is used, and that should be a simple port to Cython.  I'll try to do that in the next day or so.
content.html: I forgot we had this. It looks to me like only FindBindingEnergy from it is used, and that should be a simple port to Cython. I'll try to do that in the next day or so.

content.raw: This is great -- two quick suggestions, neither blockers.  Can we move some of the utility functions to a different file, like matplotlib does in `setupext.py`?  And is there any way we can have the extensions be a bit more terse, so that common expressions are eliminated?
content.html: This is great -- two quick suggestions, neither blockers. Can we move some of the utility functions to a different file, like matplotlib does in setupext.py? And is there any way we can have the extensions be a bit more terse, so that common expressions are eliminated?

Maybe call it `c_extensions` just so it's clearer what the contrast with cython is.
content.html: Maybe call it c_extensions just so it's clearer what the contrast with cython is.

content.raw: Actually, since we no longer cythonize by hand, it can be done the other way around: cython_extensions -> extensions
content.html: Actually, since we no longer cythonize by hand, it can be done the other way around: cython_extensions -> extensions
